awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanism-guided enzyme engineering for fucosylated glycoconjugate synthesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Glycosynthases are enzymes that have been engineered to make instead of break chains of complex sugars (oligosaccharides and carbohydrates). With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Heather Mayes from the University of Michigan and Dr. Shishir Chundawat from Rutgers University to uncover how glycosynthases synthesize prebiotic oligosaccharides or carbohydrates. These enzymes fill a pressing need in research and industrial biotechnology for the ability to produce designer carbohydrates, sugars that are designed for a specific purpose. There remains, however, a lack mechanistic understanding for how to better engineer glycosynthases to be highly specific and efficient in making complex sugars. This project combines computational and experimental studies to provide a mechanistic understanding of how a glycosynthase (alpha-L-fucosidase) catalyzes creation of specific oligosaccharides, which will in turn enable rational design of enzymes to make designer carbohydrates. The broader impacts include designing efficient routes for creating human milk oligosaccharides that could be included in infant formula to bring the composition closer to that of human milk. Human milk oligosaccharides can improve human health by promoting growth of beneficial gut bacteria and lowering incidences of other pathogenic infections. The software developed in this work for designing such enzymes will be made publicly available. Finally, the studies form the basis for outreach activities that use the biochemistry of carbohydrates to engage with students from under-resourced communities in Michigan and New Jersey.

The overall goal of this project is to understand how alpha-L-fucosidases synthesize simple glycoconjugates (e.g., human milk oligosaccharides). The hypothesis to be tested is that a priori analysis of enzyme active and binding sites, based on sequence and structural data, can be used to predict mutations that will eliminate the hydrolysis activity of the enzyme in favor of glycosidic bond synthesis of bespoke oligosaccharides. The objectives of this project are to: 1) employ experimental and computational studies to identify key structural properties that determine whether a particular enzyme mutant will be an active glycosynthase; 2) create automated processes to predict and test which mutants of disparate enzymes will be active fucosynthases; and 3) predict and test mutations needed to alter substrate specificity. The results of this feasibility study will advance the path to production of a broad suite of oligosaccharides not currently readily available for research and/or commercial applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to learn how to re-engineer a class of enzymes called “fucosynthases,” so that they can efficiently synthesize chains of sugar units, such as those in human milk. These chains of sugars are called “human milk oligosaccharides”, or HMO’s.  HMOs are necessary for healthy gut development but are not found in infant food formulations due to challenges associated with their manufacturing. Here, we focused on developing computational models to engineer the enzymes needed to make HMOs containing fucose sugar more efficiently. We propose that understanding the fucosynthase enzyme active site, using easily available sequence and structural data, can help predict how to mutate it so that it creates the glycosidic bond of HMOs. This mechanistic understanding of how fucosynthase enzymes can ultimately enable rational design of enzymes to make designer HMOs.

Towards this goal, we were successfully able to create computational models of fucosynthase using advanced molecular simulations to better understand how sugar docking in the enzyme active site leads to HMO glycosidic bond formation when using azido fucose as a donor sugar substrate. Additionally, our models generated free energy profiles of the reactions catalyzed by various fucosynthase mutants, which matched well with experimental results generated in the wet lab as well. Furthermore, we have shown that our simulations can also be used to predict additional mutations that can further improve fucosynthase activity. This approach can bypass the need for expensive experiments and complex simulations, and the results from this work are being tested by our collaborators at Rutgers University. This highlights the predictive power of advanced molecular simulations for improving enzymatic activity. Importantly, our work also provides a mechanistic basis for why fucosynthase enzymes work with azido fucose as donor sugar substrates. Machine-learning-assisted enzyme engineering methods have recently become a powerful tool in computational-guided protein engineering to optimize protein functions and identify improved enzyme mutants by optimizing sequence-function relationships. Therefore, we have also implemented next-generation computational protein design methods (e.g., AlphaFold) to further streamline our computational workflow, in synergy with high-throughput wet-lab experiments, to design more stable fucosynthase enzymes.

This project also provided a unique opportunity for interdisciplinary training of several graduate (PhD) and undergraduate students, including several students from under-represented groups, in various aspects of hands-on training on diverse areas relevant to computational biophysics, protein design/modeling, enzyme engineering, and glycosciences. Training and outreach enabled by this award has inspired several students from New Jersey and Michigan to pursue both industrial and academic careers. In particular, a former PhD student (Tucker Burgin) trained at the University of Michigan that worked on this project has recently established his independent research group specializing in the area of computational protein/enzyme design at the Dartmouth Engineering Thayer School (Dartmouth College).
